items.title: Banktivity: Your Money, Under Control
items.content_html:
In today’s fast-paced world, money moves quickly, and it can slip through your fingers like sand if you’re not paying attention. Managing your finances isn’t just about making sure you can pay the bills on time (although that’s crucial); it’s about securing your future, one dollar at a time.

Personal financial control means keeping a close watch on your financial activities, ensuring that you live within your means, and planning for the future. Here’s why it’s important:

  1. Budgeting and Spending

Knowing where your money goes each month is fundamental. By maintaining control, you can allocate funds wisely, avoid unnecessary debt, and save for future needs.

  1. Emergency Preparedness

Life is unpredictable. Having a financial cushion can help you manage unforeseen expenses without plunging into financial turmoil.

  1. Investment and Savings

Effective financial control allows you to accumulate wealth, invest in opportunities, and ensure a comfortable retirement.

  1. Debt Management

Keeping track of your debt and managing it effectively is crucial to financial health. Controlled personal finance means you can strategise to pay off debts more efficiently.

  1. Financial Goals Achievement

Whether it’s buying a home, funding education, or planning a holiday, disciplined financial management is key to achieving your goals.

Banktivity is an excellent tool for Apple users seeking to take charge of their financial destiny. By using this app, you can streamline your financial management process, making it easier to achieve your financial goals and secure your economic future.

Now, let’s talk about how Banktivity fits into this financial tapestry. For those who bleed Apple, Banktivity is the financial toolkit designed to synergise with your Apple ecosystem. Here’s why it’s a game-changer:

Banktivity integrates flawlessly with macOS and iOS, offering a user-friendly interface that feels right at home on your Apple device.

With Banktivity, budgeting becomes a breeze. The app provides detailed insights into your spending patterns, helping you stay on track with your financial goals.

Keep your investments in check with real-time portfolio updates, performance analysis, and market research tools.

Banktivity’s planning features, like scenario testing and future projections, help you navigate your financial future with confidence.

Your financial data is sensitive, and Banktivity ensures it’s safeguarded with robust encryption and security measures. All data is stored on device.

Banktivity offers tools for tracking debt, creating repayment plans, and visualising the impact of different strategies on your financial goals.

Banktivity sets itself apart from other personal finance apps offers comprehensive financial management features, superior data accuracy, and robust customer support, making it a valuable investment for serious finance management on your Mac and iOS device.

You can manually enter data into Banktivity, upload transaction data exported from you bank or connect Banktivity to your Bank to automatically download data. Importantly where available Banktivity can utilise Open Banking making the process even more secure.

After trying all the major personal finance apps such as Pocketsmith, Moneydance and Frollo the one feature that makes Banktivity standout above the other is it allows you to create multiple sets of accounts. I for example have my personal account plus separate accounts for my business, a Strata Company and 2 Trust Estates.

You can try a 30 Day free trial of Banktivity to see how well it will improve your finance management.

items.title: Automating Focus: One Shortcut to Set Up Your Project Across Finder, Notes, Reminders, DEVONthink, Obsidian, and Mail
items.content_html:
When starting a new project, speed and structure go a long way. The less time spent setting things up, the more time you can spend actually moving things forward. That’s why I built a macOS Shortcut—powered by AppleScript—that automatically creates a new Focus folder across multiple tools I use every day: Finder, Apple Notes, Reminders, DEVONthink, Obsidian, and Apple Mail.

This shortcut supports my custom productivity framework, iCRAFT, and brings consistency to my entire workflow.

⸻

🎯 What the Shortcut Does

When run, the shortcut prompts you to:

• Enter the name of your new Focus (project)

• Choose which apps you’d like to create folders for, all or a selection

Based on your selection, it will then:

• ✅ Create a new Finder folder for the project

• ✅ Create a new DEVONthink group

• ✅ Create a folder inside your Obsidian vault

• ✅ Generate a new Reminder list, either standard or from a pre-defined template

• ✅ Create an optional Apple Note that includes links to all the above folders

• ✅ Set up a new folder in Apple Mail named after the project

Everything is named consistently, placed in the right locations, and opened if needed. It’s a unified launchpad for any type of project.

⸻

🗂️ Reminders: Template or New List

For Reminders, you get two options:

  1. Start with a blank list named after your project
  2. Duplicate a template list—for example, I use a Focus Template that’s structured as a Kanban board, with sections like Backlog, In Progress, Blocked, Review and Done

This allows you to hit the ground running with a workflow that matches your needs—especially helpful for task-heavy projects.

Reminders - Focus.

⸻

📝 The Apple Note Hub (Optional)

If you choose to create an Apple Note, it acts as a lightweight dashboard. The note includes direct links to:

• 📂 The Finder folder

• 📁 The DEVONthink folder

• 📂 The Obsidian project folder

• ✅ The new Reminders list

• ✉️ Apple Mail

This makes it easy to jump between tools without hunting for the right folder each time. Of course, you can skip this step if you prefer to work app-first rather than note-first.

Apple Notes Hub

⸻

📬 Creating a Mail Folder

The Shortcut creates a new folder within your Mail app, named after the Focus. This is ideal for:

• Client-based projects

• Ongoing discussions

• Organising messages by topic or deliverable

Once created, the Mail folder is ready to receive new messages or manually filed emails—keeping your inbox clean and your project communications contained.

⸻

🧱 Designed for iCRAFT

This shortcut is fully integrated into my iCRAFT system, a structured and actionable take on Tiago Forte’s PARA method. Here’s a quick look:

• Inbox – Capture everything, no judgment

• Categories – Core areas like Business, Personal, Work, etc.

• Resources – Articles, snippets, and reference materials

• Assets – Templates, code snippets, and reusable content

• Focus – Projects that are active and moving

• Trove – Archived Focus projects for future reference

This shortcut automates setup within the Focus layer, keeping everything coordinated from the start.

⸻

💻 Mac-Only, Powered by AppleScript

Because it relies on AppleScript, this shortcut is macOS-only. But that also means it’s fast, local, and fully integrated into the Apple ecosystem. There are no third-party dependencies—just native automation using tools already on your Mac.

It’s especially useful for those who rely on DEVONthink, Obsidian, and Reminders to manage knowledge, tasks, and workflows.

You just need to set the parameters in the script to suit your needs

If you don’t have, or want, all of the apps the script covers you just change the following settings to false

⸻

🧪 Example: New Focus in Action

Let’s say I’m starting a new training course. I would

  1. Trigger the shortcut and enter “Building a 2nd Brain”
  2. Choose to create:

• Finder folder ✅

• DEVONthink group ✅

• Obsidian folder ✅

• Reminder list (using my Kanban-style template) ✅

• Apple Note ✅

• Mail folder ✅

  1. The shortcut does the rest: creates folders, adds links, and gets everything ready.

Within seconds, I have a consistent, structured workspace for the project—across every app I use to manage it.

Here is a video that includes a demonstration of the generation of the folders

⸻

🔁 Reusable, Repeatable, Reliable

This shortcut has become my go-to method for launching new projects. It reduces setup time, prevents folder chaos, and ensures I start every Focus with the same solid foundation.

If you’re a Mac user juggling multiple tools, I highly recommend setting something like this up. My process is available via Gumroad for $5, or via a membership to my suite of Apple Product focussed Shortcuts for only $10.

When everything starts in the same way, you can focus on the work—not finding your files.

items.title: Why I Chose the ORICO CyberData CF56 Pro Over Synology, QNAP, and UGREEN for My Next-Gen Homelab NAS
items.content_text:
If you’re in the market for a powerful, flexible NAS that won’t box you in with artificial restrictions, look beyond the usual suspects. After years with the reliable but aging Synology DS218+, I finally pulled the trigger on a major upgrade: the ORICO CyberData CF56 Pro.

And here’s why that decision wasn’t just about specs — it was about freedom.

⸻

🚫 Why Synology, QNAP, UGREEN and Zettlab Didn’t Make the Cut

Let’s break this down:

 • Synology: Once the darling of the NAS world, Synology has taken a hard left into walled-garden territory. Between crippling hardware restrictions, removing apps, and OS lock-ins, the once flexible ecosystem now feels like a premium-priced handcuff. I need a NAS that works for me, not the other way around.

 • QNAP: QNAP’s hardware lineup is frustratingly constrained. Most models are under powered, have limited expansion options, or are priced into workstation territory. Not ideal when I want a serious homelab server that can scale.

 • UGREEN: Some exciting early promise — but you can’t even buy them in Australia. That’s a dealbreaker. Marketing teams, take note: ignoring an entire continent that’s not just bad logistics, it’s bad strategy.

 • Zettlab: These guys are interesting. They’ve entered the scene with some promising-looking NAS hardware that targets prosumers. On paper, their gear is competitive — but being new comes with caveats. There’s limited info on delivery times, after-sales support, or software maturity. Worth watching, but not betting my homelab on them just yet.

⸻

✅ Enter the ORICO CF56 Pro — A Sleeper Hit With Serious Power

ORICO isn’t always top-of-mind when it comes to NAS, but the CyberData CF56 Pro deserves your full attention. Here’s what made me a believer:

🔧 Hardware Specs That Matter

Component Spec

CPU Intel Core i5-1240P (12-core, 16-thread)

GPU Integrated Intel Iris Xe Graphics

RAM 16GB DDR5 (Expandable to 96GB)

Drive Bays 5x SATA III (3.5”/2.5” compatible)

Dual PCIe 4.0 x4 M.2 NVMe Slots (great for cache)

Four PCIe 3.0 x2 M.2 NVMe Slots

LAN dual 10GbE ports

40Gbps USB4 ports (supports Thunderbolt 4/3)

Expansion HDMI, DPI, USB 3.2 Gen2 x2 (USB C & A), USB 2.0 X 2, External GPU ready

Cooling Large smart fans, clean internal airflow

Build Full aluminum alloy case, clean design

This thing is not your typical underpowered ARM box. With a 10-core Intel chip and real GPU, it’s ready for VMs, containers, media transcoding, AI tools, or just screaming-fast file access.

⸻

🧠 OS Flexibility: Use Theirs or Roll Your Own

The CF56 Pro ships with CyberData OS, a Linux-based system with a clean UI. I’ll give it a fair shake, but the beauty is: I’m not locked in.

Whether it’s:

 • TrueNAS SCALE

 • UnRAID

 • OpenMediaVault

 • Debian/Ubuntu with Cockpit

 • Proxmox for full virtualization

…you can install it. No hoops. No hacks. No “not supported” pop-ups.

⸻

💻 Why It’s Perfect for My Homelab

I needed a system that could:

 • Act as a NAS and hypervisor

 • Run Docker & K8s clusters

 • Host AI models locally

 • Serve as a Plex or Jellyfin box

 • Provide Git, Syncthing, Nextcloud, etc.

The ORICO CF56 Pro checks every box. And unlike proprietary systems, it won’t fight me every time I want to customize it.

{{< youtube DuPgN90dH38>}}

⸻

Final Thoughts: Don’t Sleep on ORICO

The ORICO CyberData CF56 Pro feels like that one product you discover before everyone else catches on. It’s overpowered for its price point, beautifully built, and — most importantly — free of ecosystem handcuffs.

If you’re tired of being locked out of your own gear, this is the NAS your homelab deserves.

The Kickstarter campaign ends soon, some great savings can be had if you are quick, more info can be found via this link.

items.title: Productivity Isn’t One-Size-Fits-All—It’s CRAFTed
items.content_text:
Productivity systems are everywhere. PARA. Zettelkasten. Johnny.Decimal. Second Brains. If you’ve spent any time optimising your workflow you’ve likely run into one of these.

Of them all, Tiago Forte’s PARA system—Projects, Areas, Resources, Archives—is arguably the most popular. It’s elegant, flexible, and beloved by many. And yet, like any one-size-fits-all system, it has a flaw:

It’s not you.

Let me explain—with a system I call iCRAFT.

⸻

🔍 A Quick Look at PARA

If you’ve somehow dodged the PARA craze, here’s a crash course:

 • Projects – Things you’re actively working on with a clear goal and deadline.

 • Areas – Long-term responsibilities like health, family, finances, or professional development.

 • Resources – Topic-based references or learning materials.

 • Archives – Stuff you’ve finished, paused, or shelved.

It’s designed to work across any platform—from Notion and Obsidian to your local file system. It’s simple, and it works. For many.

But I found myself constantly tweaking PARA to suit my mental flow. Eventually, I realised I wasn’t “using PARA with tweaks” anymore. I’d created something entirely my own.

⸻

🧩 The Problem with Productivity Systems

Here’s the thing: most systems are built for someone else’s brain.

You might follow PARA to the letter and still feel friction. Or implement Zettelkasten perfectly but struggle to find anything. Because they’re starting points, not commandments.

And if you’re trying to be more organised, less stressed, or just stop forgetting things, you need a system that feels intuitive. One that makes sense to you.

So, I created iCRAFT. Think of it as a remix of PARA—with structure inspired by Forte, but tailored to how I work and live.

⸻

🛠️ Meet iCRAFT

Here’s what iCRAFT stands for:

Inbox

This is my messy holding zone. Quick notes, ideas, screenshots, articles to read, things I haven’t processed yet—they all land here first. Nothing’s organised yet. That’s the point.

Categories

This is where life gets segmented into meaningful buckets. Instead of vague “areas,” I wanted something more practical. These are the core domains of my life:

 • 📂 Business

 • 📂 Finance

 • 📂 Home

 • 📂 Personal

 • 📂 Recreation

 • 📂 Work

When I’m filing something, I don’t ask “is this a project or area?” I ask: “What part of life does this belong to?”

I use these same categories across multiple apps, Mail, Notes, Reminders etc,  to make information organisation and retrieval so much easier.

Resources

These are articles, topic snippets, research clippings, white papers—reference materials, not action items. Things I might want to revisit or learn from, but not act on immediately.

Assets

This is my reuse zone. Templates, media, code, clipart, quotes, email drafts, automation scripts—anything I might use again in another context.

Focus

This is where my energy goes. These are current, active projects or priorities. Whether it’s launching something new, writing, renovating, or planning a trip—if it matters right now, it lives here.

Trove

This is where finished or shelved projects go. “Trove” feels less like a dusty attic and more like a treasure chest of past work. It’s not where things go to die—it’s where they rest until they’re needed again.

⸻

🤔 Why iCRAFT Works for Me

The secret sauce? iCRAFT mirrors how I think.

 • I want clearer life domains—hence the Categories.

 • I separate reference material (Resources) from reusable building blocks (Assets).

 • I swapped “Projects” for Focus because sometimes the thing I’m working on doesn’t fit neatly into the “project” definition.

 • And “Trove” feels more purposeful than “Archive”—it’s where I store value, not just clutter.

This system doesn’t make me more productive in a performative sense. It makes me calmer, clearer, and more in control. That’s the real win.

{{< youtube SeuckvmamX8 >}}

⸻

📣 The Takeaway: Customise Everything

You don’t need to use iCRAFT (although you’re welcome to). You don’t need to stick to PARA, Johnny.Decimal, or Notion templates you found online.

What you need is a system that reflects how you think and how you live.

Start with a framework, sure. But bend it. Break it. Rename it. Translate it into your world

That’s how PARA became iCRAFT.

So, what would your system look like?

items.title: Finding James Spencer
items.content_text:
On the 110th anniversary of the Gallipoli landing I am reposting an article I wrote tracing the true identity of my Grandfather, James Spencer, a veteran of that campaign.

I have had a passion for tracing my family tree for some years. On my father’s paternal side, I can trace the Dunn family back to the 1500s. On my mother’s paternal side, I hit a roadblock with her father, James Spencer.

James came to Western Australia from Scotland in 1921 after serving as a Private in the British Army from 1909 to 1921. He married my grandmother, Louisa Collins, in Perth in 1924. They had two children, Hazel, my mother, and Jean.

James worked on sheep stations, as a cook in hotels and as a gardener. When World War 2 came around, he enlisted in the Australian Army and served from 1939 until 1947, achieving the rank of Corporal.

James passed away in 1951, 14 years before I was born.

In World War 1, James served in several theatres, including Eqypt, The Dardanelles and France. James received a head wound at Gallipoli in 1914 and was evacuated to France to recover.

As a side note, having a family member who fought at Gallipoli is a source of pride for an Australian, though unfortunately, he was not an ANZAC.

In 1930, he lodged a claim for a British Army pension due to the ongoing effects he suffered from the wounding, basically loss of hearing and dizziness and problems with his feet from fighting in the trenches in France, ultimately, the application was turned down. To evaluate his claim, all of his British Army records were sent to Australia. The records then ended up in the Australian National Archives.

On James’s Wedding Certificate, it states he was born in Glasgow, Scotland, in 1896. It lists his father as James Spencer, a Shipyard Worker, and his mother as Margaret Webster.

His Death certificate records his father as being James Spencer, a dairy farmer, and his mother as Margaret Webster. His place of birth was Dundee, Scotland, and his birth year was 1885.

Generally, with the information available on these certificates, it would be fairly easy to trace his family via Birth, Wedding or Death Certificates and Census information. In James’s case, I could get nowhere. I could not locate his birth certificate or a wedding certificate for James Spencer and Margaret Webster.

Luckily, I could access his British Army records at the National Archives. I hoped to get additional information on James to help me trace him. But the result was actually more confusion as James listed 3 different places and dates of birth.

Apart from the information I gleaned from the Army records on his extensive military action and physical characteristics (he was only 5’2’), I found details on his vices, drinking, gambling, and being absent without leave.  Unfortunately, I also saw treatment for socially induced ailments that a Grandson could have gone without knowing 😀.  All in all, I got the impression he was a loveable rogue who didn't shirk his duty to serve his country, and I really feel slighted not to have had the opportunity to know him.

The Army records also mentioned that his next of kin was his wife but did not mention her name, just a c/- address, Mrs E Burgess in Dundee, Scotland. This was a surprise but gave me some additional hope as if he was married, there would be a marriage certificate that may provide additional information to help trace him. I had a thought that maybe James had married a daughter of Mrs Burgess. Unfortunately, my search again came up empty.  

At about this time, I engaged a couple of professional Genealogists in Scotland to see if they could assist. Both came back within days and said that they could not help.

One avenue that I thought may assist was if I could obtain additional information from his regiment museum, the King’s Own Scottish Borderers (KOSB) in Berwick-upon-Tweed, England. Unfortunately, they had stopped assisting with family tree enquiries.

I kept looking for any potential leads for the next few years but got no further.

When visiting my Aunt Jean in Margaret River, I would ask questions about her father to see if I could glean some valuable information. Aunty Jean advised that her father celebrated his birthday on the 3rd of September. I am not sure why it took so long, but in one of my last visits with her, before she passed away in 2022 at the age of 94, she provided two bits of information that would reset my search parameters.

“I think he or his father changed their name from MacPherson” and “Margeret Webster may be his stepmother.”

With this information, I was back to square one. If he had changed his surname, did he also change his first name? Basically, I was uncertain of his name, place of birth, date of birth and parents.

The mention of MacPherson twigged my memory as James had recorded his previous employer on one of his British Army enlistment papers as being “Colin MacPherson, Market Gardener, Deceased.”

 

In early 2023, I noticed on the website of the KOSB Museum that they were now providing family tree research assistance. I sent off my request, and I eventually got a reply advising that they had James’s discharge statement from the British Army. I was then advised that the information could be collected, but there was the issue of the museum closing in August for 3 years due to renovations. 

I was already planning to visit Woodstock, Illinois, to attend the annual Macstock convention in late July, so I arranged my itinerary so I could get to the Museum on Friday, the 28th of July.

While waiting to take my trip, I engaged the services of the Research Team at the Tay Valley Family History Society to see if they could assist in locating my grandfather. They conducted a lot of research and came to the same conclusion that he could not be traced based on the available information. They were now invested in the search and were waiting to see what information I could obtain from the KOSB Museum.

I attended the KOSB museum and collected the available information. Most of the information I had already obtained regarding his service in the Army, the one new piece of information, was the mention of a marriage to Jemima Burgess in Dundee on 5 October 1915 on his discharge papers.

After leaving the museum, I was driving up to Inverness to do some Nessie hunting (unsuccessful😀 ) so I emailed the new information to the Research Team. By the time I arrived at Inverness, I had an email that provided the breakthrough that I had been searching for.

They had checked Scotlands People (the Scottish Government site for searching government records and archives) for a Marriage Certificate between James Spencer and Jemima Burgess. That search was unsuccessful, but they did find a marriage on the same day between John Robertson MacPherson and Jemima Burgess. Jemima lived at 26 Mid Street Dundee, the same address James had listed as the C/- address for his unnamed wife.

John MacPherson listed his father as Colin MacPherson, Market Gardener, Deceased, and his mother as Margaret MacPherson, maiden name Robertson. He also stated his occupation as being a Private in the King’s Own Scottish Borderers.

A search of Scottish Birth and Census records shows that Colin MacPherson was actually John/James’s grandfather. His mother was Margaret MacPherson, the daughter of Colin. Colin’s wife was Agnes Webster. Either on purpose or by confusion, James had mixed up his mother’s and grandmother's names to use Margeret Webster on his Marriage Certificate.

John Macpherson’s birth certificate confirms his date of birth to be 3 September 1884 and his place of birth to be Dundee. It lists Margaret MacPherson as his mother, with no name for his father. I am taking a punt that John’s middle name, Robertson, is likely his father's Surname. Of interest is in the 1881 Census, the MacPhersons lived in the same house as a Robertson family. I am hoping DNA may eventually confirm this theory.

A search on Fold3 for military records for John MacPherson came up with this index card from the Western Front Association archive.

It would appear that the British Army were aware of James's true identity. All of the Regiments listed are the same as recorded under James Spencer’s index card. It is strange in the 100+ pages of records that I accessed at the National Archive, this was never mentioned; it would have saved a lot of time.

Jemima eventually filed for Divorce from John MacPherson (address unknown) in 1938. I wonder what the reason was for the breakdown of the marriage?  I feel sorry for Jemima for the position I imagine she was left in when James left for Australia. I will be undertaking further research to try and gain insight into her life.

It may have taken years, but the effort was worthwhile as I now have a better understanding of my grandfather, James Spencer, formerly known as John MacPherson. I can also add bigamy to his list of vices 😀.

Though for the many answered questions, I now have more questions to pursue. Fortunately, as time goes by, more and more information gets digitised, more people post details of their family tree, and more DNA tests get taken; it's not always easy, but researching your family tree can be very rewarding.

items.title: Exploring Creative Space: The Game-Changing Software for XTool Users
items.content_html:
Introduction: When it comes to laser engraving and cutting, having the right tools can significantly impact your creative output. For users of XTool devices, Creative Space software emerges as a standout feature that enhances both the flexibility and ease of their projects. In this blog, we’ll explore why Creative Space software is not just an accessory but a necessity for anyone looking to leverage their XTool to its fullest potential.

Creative Space: A Hub of Innovation Creative Space software is specifically designed to be user-friendly while offering advanced features that cater to the needs of both beginners and seasoned professionals. What makes it truly exceptional is its intuitive interface, which simplifies the process of designing, editing, and managing engraving or cutting projects. Here’s a look at some of the key features that make Creative Space a vital tool for XTool users.

1. User-Friendly Design Tools: First and foremost, Creative Space is acclaimed for its accessibility. The software offers a variety of pre-set templates and design tools that help users jumpstart their projects. Even those with limited graphic design experience can find their footing quickly, thanks to drag-and-drop functionality and easy navigation controls. This lowers the barrier to entry, making laser engraving a more inclusive craft.

2. Seamless Integration with XTool Machines: Creative Space is not just any design software; it’s tailor-made for XTool machines. This means that the compatibility and communication between the software and the hardware are seamless. Users can expect smooth transitions from design to execution, with minimal setup and calibration needed. This integration reduces project time and enhances the overall quality of the final product.

3. Real-Time Preview and Adjustments: One of the standout features of Creative Space is its real-time preview capability. Users can visualize exactly how their design will look on the material before making the first cut or engrave. This is particularly useful when working with expensive materials or complex designs, as it minimizes waste and ensures that the end results match the user’s expectations. Adjustments can be made on the fly, adding to the convenience.

4. Extensive Material Library: Creative Space comes equipped with an extensive material library that provides users with parameters and settings for various materials. Whether you’re working with leather, wood, acrylic, or metal, the software offers guidance on the optimal settings for cutting or engraving. This feature is invaluable for those experimenting with new materials or striving to achieve the best results without extensive trial and error.

5. Community-Driven Updates and Support: Lastly, Creative Space is continuously evolving, thanks to a community-driven approach to updates and features. XTool and its users contribute to a feedback loop that ensures the software meets the growing demands of the engraving and cutting community. This collaborative approach ensures that Creative Space remains on the cutting edge of design software, with regular updates that introduce new features and improvements.

Conclusion: Your Creative Ally Creative Space software isn’t just a tool; it’s a partner in your creative journey. It offers the ease of use, integration, real-time feedback, and material guidance necessary to transform your creative ideas into reality. For XTool users, it enhances the experience by simplifying the technical aspects of laser engraving and cutting, allowing more time and energy to be spent on the creative process. Whether you’re a hobbyist or a professional, Creative Space is your ally in pushing the boundaries of what’s possible with an XTool.

If you have specific questions about Creative Space or want to delve deeper into how it can be tailored to your projects, feel free to reach out or comment below. Let’s unleash the full potential of your XTool together!

items.title: Why the XTool S1 Enclosed Laser is the Best Choice for Laser Engraving Enthusiasts
items.content_html:
Introduction

A natural progression from my 3d printing hobby was to look at acquiring a laser engraver. My preference is to buy into an ecosystem, where the hardware and software is tightly aligned, such as market leaders Apple and Bambu Lab. My other preference was an enclosed design. I looked at offers from Creality and RoIy Automation but there were issues with quality of design and materials or reliance on third party software that could leave you stranded and limits the potential for feature improvements.

XTools: The obvious choice

In the end I chose the XTool S1 Enclosed Laser as it met all my requirements, plus its beautiful design gained Wife approval 😀, the other options are not so easy on the eye . Praised for its innovation and safety features, the S1 model is tailor-made for users who demand precision, efficiency, and reliability. In this deep dive, we will explore the multifaceted advantages of the XTool S1, highlighting why it’s a leading choice in the laser engraving industry.

Safety First: A Closed Design That Cares

One of the standout features of the XTool S1 is its enclosed design. This isn’t just about aesthetics; it’s about safety. Laser engravers, by nature, can be dangerous. The enclosed casing of the XTool S1 significantly reduces the risks associated with direct exposure to the laser beam. This design not only protects the user from accidental exposure but also helps in containing the fumes and particles produced during the engraving process. It’s especially beneficial in educational settings or home environments where safety is a paramount concern.

Precision and Power: Unmatched Quality

At the heart of the XTool S1’s appeal is its extraordinary precision. Equipped with a high-quality laser, this machine can achieve detailed engravings on a variety of materials, from wood and leather to some metals and plastics. What sets it apart is the consistency of the results, whether you’re working on intricate designs for jewellery or customising industrial components. The S1’s robust construction minimises vibrations, ensuring that even the most delicate work is sharp and clear.

User-Friendly Experience: Easy Does It

Another significant advantage of the XTool S1 is its user-friendliness. It is designed not just for skilled artisans but also for beginners. The setup process is straightforward, and the learning curve is gentle, thanks to its intuitive software interface. The software supports multiple file formats, allowing users to effortlessly import designs or create them in the application. Furthermore, the XTool S1 provides real-time previews, which means users can see exactly how their designs will look before the engraving begins. This feature saves time and materials by reducing errors.

Creative Space: A Hub of Innovation

XTool’s Creative Space software is specifically designed to be user-friendly while offering advanced features that cater to the needs of both beginners and seasoned professionals. What makes it truly exceptional is its intuitive interface, which simplifies the process of designing, editing, and managing engraving or cutting projects. Here’s a look at some of the key features that make Creative Space a vital tool for XTool users.

  1. User-Friendly Design Tools

First and foremost, Creative Space is acclaimed for its accessibility. The software offers a variety of pre-set templates and design tools that help users jumpstart their projects. Even those with limited graphic design experience can find their footing quickly, thanks to drag-and-drop functionality and easy navigation controls. This lowers the barrier to entry, making laser engraving a more inclusive craft.

  1. Seamless Integration with XTool Machines

Creative Space is not just any design software; it’s tailor-made for XTool machines. This means that the compatibility and communication between the software and the hardware are seamless. Users can expect smooth transitions from design to execution, with minimal setup and calibration needed. This integration reduces project time and enhances the overall quality of the final product.

  1. Real-Time Preview and Adjustments

One of the standout features of Creative Space is its real-time preview capability. Users can visualize exactly how their design will look on the material before making the first cut or engrave. This is particularly useful when working with expensive materials or complex designs, as it minimizes waste and ensures that the end results match the user’s expectations. Adjustments can be made on the fly, adding to the convenience.

  1. Extensive Material Library

Creative Space comes equipped with an extensive material library that provides users with parameters and settings for various materials. Whether you’re working with leather, wood, acrylic, or metal, the software offers guidance on the optimal settings for cutting or engraving. This feature is invaluable for those experimenting with new materials or striving to achieve the best results without extensive trial and error.

  1. Community-Driven Updates and Support

Lastly, Creative Space is continuously evolving, thanks to a community-driven approach to updates and features. XTool and its users contribute to a feedback loop that ensures the software meets the growing demands of the engraving and cutting community. This collaborative approach ensures that Creative Space remains on the cutting edge of design software, with regular updates that introduce new features and improvements. An example of this is the recently introduced feature where you can use your phone camera to identity the location of the material on the tray and apply designs to each material piece automatically, to see this in action watch this amazing video where XTool demonstrated engraving randomly placed toothpicks (51m20s).

Versatility at Its Best: Wide Material Compatibility

Versatility is key in choosing a laser engraver, and the XTool S1 shines in this department. It’s equipped to handle a wide range of materials, giving users the flexibility to explore different projects and applications. Whether you’re a hobbyist interested in personalised gifts or a small business focused on bespoke products, the XTool S1 can meet your needs. Its ability to adapt to different materials and thicknesses without compromising on quality makes it an invaluable tool in any creative arsenal.

Community and Support: You’re Not Alone

Buying an XTool S1 means getting access to a vibrant community of fellow engravers and a reliable customer support team. New users can benefit from a plethora of tutorials, community forums, and direct support from XTool. For professionals, the community offers a platform to share techniques, solutions, and inspiration. This kind of support ecosystem not only enhances the user experience but also fosters a culture of learning and innovation.

A key feature of 3D Printing is the ability to modify your machine using community provided mods, and the XTools users offer the same assistance . In my case the location of the S1 limited the natural path for the exhaust duct so I printed this modification that allowed for a slimmed down rear exhaust path.

Conclusion: The Engraver’s Choice

In summary, the XTool S1 Enclosed Laser isn’t just an engraving machine; it’s a gateway to expanding your creative potential. Its safety features, precision, user-friendliness, material versatility, and strong community support make it a top choice for anyone serious about laser engraving. Whether you’re starting a new hobby or scaling up a business, the XTool S1 is designed to be your partner in the journey of creation. Dive into the world of laser engraving with confidence and let your imagination take physical form with the XTool S1!

items.title: Bambu Labs: Leading the 3D Printing Revolution with Superior Products and Software
items.content_html:
Revolutionising the Industry with Innovative Technology

I first got into 3d printing while helping a family member put together a Prusa Mini knockoff. kit. That process was not enjoyable and the finished product was lack lustere in performance, but it tweaked my interest in the 3d printing world,

I then bought a FlashForge Adventurer 3 and used it successfully for several years. That printer worked well but it was slow and the build dimensions limited my options with what models I could print.

From afar I observed that Bambu Lab was swiftly rising to prominence in the 3D printing world, thanks to its relentless pursuit of innovation. Founded by a team of passionate engineers and designers, the company aims to make 3D printing more accessible, efficient, and versatile for users at all levels. What sets Bambu Labs apart is not just the quality of its printers but also the sophisticated software that drives them, alongside revolutionary features like the Automatic Material Switching (AMS) system.

The P1S: A Beacon of Quality and Performance

At the heart of Bambu Labs’ product line is the Bambu Labs P1S, a fully enclosed 3D printer that embodies the company’s commitment to excellence. Known for its remarkable speed and precision, the P1S is powered by proprietary technology that optimises print time without compromising on detail or quality. Its features include:

High-Speed Printing: Utilising a unique X/Y core motion system, the P1S can print at speeds unheard of in similarly priced models. Precision Printing: Advanced extrusion technology ensures that every layer of your print is exact, reducing the need for post-processing.

These features make the P1S not just a tool, but a gateway to exploring the possibilities of 3D printing.

Software Superiority: Simplifying Complexity

What really elevates Bambu Labs above the competition is its integrated software solutions. These are designed to enhance the user experience, streamline the printing process, and unlock new potentials in 3D design. The software suite offers:

Automatic Error Correction: It detects potential issues before they become problems, saving time and resources. Seamless Integration: From design software to the printing interface, everything works together flawlessly, ensuring a smooth workflow. Regular Updates: Bambu Labs is committed to continuous improvement, frequently releasing software updates that enhance functionality and user experience.

Automatic Material Switching (AMS): A Game Changer

Perhaps the most revolutionary feature offered by Bambu Labs is the Automatic Material Switching (AMS) system. This system allows users to automatically switch between different types of filament during a single print job, which can significantly enhance the creative capabilities of any designer. The AMS is particularly useful for:

Complex Multi-Material Projects: Easily switch between different materials to achieve varied textures and strengths within a single object. High-Volume Printing Operations: Reduce downtime by automatically switching to a new filament spool when one runs out. Enhanced Color Options: Create vibrant, coloured objects without manual intervention.

Community Support: Ongoing Improvement As good as the design of the P1S is there is always room for improvement. One of the beauties of the 3D printing scene is the development and availability of community modifications. In my case I have enhanced the P1S with the following modifications

Xtouch LCD Screen - Duplicates a lot of the functions of the big brother X1 Carbon’s screen. Low Profile Riser - to add a led strip to improve lighting. Bowden Tube Y Splitter - removes requiement to remove AMS filament when using a manual filament spool. Build Plate Guide - allows easy alignment of the build plate.

Bambu Labs: A Synonym for Innovation With its robust product offerings, superior software, and innovative AMS system, Bambu Labs has set a new standard in 3D printing. The company’s dedication to breaking barriers and pushing boundaries in 3D technology makes it a leader in the field. Whether you are a hobbyist, a professional designer, or someone looking to explore the potential of 3D printing, Bambu Labs offers tools that will not only meet but exceed your expectations.

Final Thoughts As 3D printing continues to evolve, choosing a company that stays ahead of technological advancements and offers reliable, innovative solutions is crucial. Bambu Labs exemplifies such a choice, with its blend of advanced technology, user-focused design, and revolutionary features like the AMS. For anyone serious about 3D printing, investing in Bambu Labs means investing in the future of fabrication.
